15. Some people accuse us
of never painting fine weather,
but the Sky is always changeable and full of clouds,
grudging Apollo almost a tiny hollow
through which he can cast his gaze downward
toward his Mother, which dissatisfies him,
and the flowers who love him
turn in vain to receive his beautiful gaze.
left-middlePainters are accused of never painting fine weather, but perpetually cloudy Sky.

16. To avert all this unpleasantness,
let us now clear the Sky of clouds,
and at times display it entirely pure
in the clearest azure or smalt,
though with clean tools, to stay spotless:
and the lower down the lighter it is, gently dissipating
so that next to the heaviness of the Earthly Element
it will always be, as is fitting, the brightest of all.
left-middleMaking entirely pure blue Skies, growing brighter lower down.

17. When we wish to display the full Sun,
we should crown it with a light lake,
somewhat purplish, blending it throughout.
Yet all the same, such brilliant substance
will always elude us, beyond our powers.
While our Art is noble, so vast, so splendid,
here we must rightly reproach our own work,
since our Torches will never glow as brightly.
left-middleTo paint the Sun, though none can imitate its brilliance.

18. Unless we knew how to commit
(as the Poets say) a celestial theft
in the quadriga of Prometheus.
But fearing punishment, and to please ourselves,
let us descend to the earthly plane,
proceeding at once to the planes of the Landscape
which one works, on canvas or panel,
to divide into or three or four.
left-middleDividing the planes of the Landscape.

19. First of all, our foreground should appear
properly solid, set off from the rest.
Bring forward something large,
like Bruegel, and other such famous names
to whom we offer the palm in Landscape.
For in the work of these worthy Persons
There are many mighty tree trunks in front;
Let us eagerly imitate them.
